I‚Äôm writing this review to warn others‚Ä¶I‚Äôm writing this review to warn others about a very misleading and disappointing experience. I booked a flight + hotel package through Expedia, assuming that the flights and hotel would be compatible. After booking, the hotel emailed me to say their check-in closes at 5 PM‚Äîwhich is shocking for any property, especially one being sold as part of an evening-arrival package. My flight, which Expedia paired with this hotel, wasn‚Äôt scheduled to land until 8 PM, making it impossible to arrive in time.Because of this, I had no choice but to cancel. While the hotel‚Äôs policy may have been technically ‚Äúclear,‚Äù it is completely unreasonable for a hotel to participate in package deals while enforcing a check-in time earlier than most people‚Äôs workday even ends. A hotel offering check-in only until 5 PM should be upfront about this before purchase‚Äînot after the booking is completed.Expedia attempted to contact the hotel on my behalf for a refund, but the hotel refused to provide any accommodation, flexibility, or even basic understanding of the situation. Their stance felt rigid and customer-unfriendly, especially given that the timing issue was not caused by me.To add insult to injury, I‚Äôm a Platinum Expedia member, yet because the hotel was cancelled (without refund), I‚Äôm also denied Expedia points, even though I still paid the fees.Between Expedia selling an incompatible package and the hotel refusing to work with guests who physically can‚Äôt meet their unusual check-in window, the entire situation feels scammy and unfair. If you‚Äôre considering booking this hotel‚Äîor any package with Expedia‚Äîbe extremely cautious.November 23, 2025Unprompted review

Just Like the MafiaUse these people and you will lose money, not save it.   You have to sort through all the airlines' policies and ignore their statements to know what is refundable. At the top of the page it says, "No fee if cancelled before December 9".  That's the hotel.  It's up to you to know the airlines' policy which has nothing to do with their statement.  Yeah, just like the hotel has their own policy.  Which doesn't apply because you're going through Expedia.  But the airlines' policy DOES apply.  I just lost $500 with their doing that.Also, they're an online, software based travel integrator.  The software is typical IT fraud that does not ever work right.  #1 sin for a business like that, they have very poor integration with what they offer.  If you book a fully refundable room, then decide to cancel within the grace period...you can't!  The hotel cannot do it and you have to do it through Expedia.  I had a room at a hotel that was willing to give me a refund on a fully refundable room as my wife had become ill at the last second and I couldn't call until the next day- but they couldn't because it was booked through Expedia.  They said I had to work with them, they could call the hotel, everything was fine with them about the refund.  Good luck trying to get that done with Expedia.  Bottom line, Expedia tells you to call the hotel.  "Oh, we can't make changes with Spirit Airlines.  You have to call them yourself" (why am I using this in the first place...)  OK.  They don't have a phone number.  The vitual assistant is total crap.  So you jump through hoops to cancel with Spirit, and Expedia still shows you're booked.  I was able to dig up a phone number (800-319-4834) and ask to have the data fixed.  "Oh, Spirit won't let us do that".  I'll fix that; I'll delete the account. Serious data-sharing and brand-damaging by Expedia that every hotelier should be aware ofI am posting this review to warn other hoteliers about practices that can seriously damage your brand without your knowledge.We recently discovered that Expedia Private Label Solutions was sharing our property listings, photos, data and even room descriptions with unverified third-party websites that we had never heard of and never authorized.Two of these websites were:‚Ä¢ VaudHotels ‚Äì which displays photos of rooms that do not even exist in our property, cannot be contacted, and has no legal information available anywhere online‚Ä¢ HotelsOne.com ‚Äì whose management confirmed in writing that they receive our listings directly from Expedia Private Label SolutionsBoth of these websites have already been reported to the Swiss authorities, and I am prepared to do the same with Expedia if this continues.The most concerning part is that when I asked Expedia for the full list of OTA partners, affiliates, and resellers who receive our data, they refused to provide it.This means that there are certainly more websites out there using our name, our rooms, our prices, and our photos without our authorization ‚Äì and Expedia will not tell us who they are.This raises serious issues:‚Ä¢ Damage to brand image and reputation‚Ä¢ Incorrect prices and misleading information published without your knowledge‚Ä¢ Non-existent room types circulating on the internet under your name‚Ä¢ Guests unable to reach these ‚Äúpartners,‚Äù blaming the hotel instead‚Ä¢ Lack of transparency by Expedia despite repeated written requestsExpedia is the only OTA with which we have ever experienced such chaos and lack of transparency.We work with many other channels and have never encountered anything comparable.If you are a hotelier, check where your listings are appearing.Your property may be published on dozens of unauthorized websites through Expedia‚Äôs private-label distribution chain,
